com.stormpath.sdk.servlet.api

Interface ServletApiRequestAuthenticator

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    DefaultServletApiRequestAuthenticator

    public interface ServletApiRequestAuthenticator
    Since:
    1.0.RC4.6

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      ApiAuthenticationResult authenticate(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest httpServletRequest)
      Authenticates an HttpServletRequest request submitted to your application's API, returning a result that reflects the successfully authenticated Account that made the request and the ApiKey used to authenticate the request.

    • Method Detail

      • authenticate

        ApiAuthenticationResult authenticate(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest httpServletRequest)
        Authenticates an HttpServletRequest request submitted to your application's API, returning a result that reflects the successfully authenticated Account that made the request and the ApiKey used to authenticate the request. Throws a ResourceException if the request cannot be authenticated.

        This method will automatically authenticate both HTTP Basic and OAuth 2 requests. However, if you require more specific or customized OAuth request processing, use the ServletOAuthRequestAuthenticator.authenticate(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest) method instead; that method allows you to customize how an OAuth request is processed. For example, you will likely want to call ServletOAuthRequestAuthenticator.authenticate(HttpServletRequest) for requests directed to your application's specific OAuth 2 token and authorization urls (often referenced as /oauth2/token and /oauth2/authorize in OAuth 2 documentation).

        The concrete type of the authentication result will depend on the request type, and can be resolved to the specific type using a AuthenticationResultVisitor.

        Basic Example

        //assume a request to, say, https://api.mycompany.com/foo: public void onApiRequest(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) {     ApiAuthenticationResult result = Servlets.servletApiRequestAuthenticator(application).authenticate(); Account account = result.getAccount(); // Check to see that account is allowed to make this request or not before processing // the request. For example, by checking the account's groups or any of your own // application-specific permissions that might exist in the group's or account's customData. assertAuthorized(account); //implement the 'assertAuthorized' method yourself. //process request here }

        OAuth 2 Example

        The above example is generic - it assumes either HTTP Basic or OAuth 2 authentication, and do not distinguish between the two. This is totally fine if that is suitable for your application.

        However, OAuth 2 also has the notion of scopes, also known as application-specific permissions. If the request is an OAuth 2 request, and you have authenticate(HttpServletRequest) previously assigned scopes to OAuth tokens} you can check those scopes during an API request to control access.

        So how do we do that? How do we know if a request was a regular HTTP Basic request or an OAuth 2 request? We use an AuthenticationResultVisitor. This will allow us - in a compile-time/type-safe way to react to whatever is returned by the authenticate method. For example:

         //assume a request to, say, https://api.mycompany.com/foo:

 public void onApiRequest(HttpServletRequest /* or your framework-specific request - see above */ request) {

      ApiAuthenticationResult result = Servlets.servletApiRequestAuthenticator(application).authenticate(request);

      final Set<String> scope = new LinkedHashSet<String>;

      result.accept(new AuthenticationResultVisitor() {

        @Override
        public void visit(ApiAuthenticationResult result) {
            //the request was a normal HTTP Basic request
        }

        @Override
        public void visit(OAuthAuthenticationResult result) {
            //the request was authenticated using OAuth
            //ensure we can use the scopes for access control checks after this visitor returns:
            scope.addAll(result.getScope());
        }
        ...
    });

    Account account = result.getAccount();

    // Check to see that account is allowed to make this request or not before processing the request:
    // check the scope here for any permissions that are required for this API call.  You can also check
    // the account's groups or any of your own
    // application-specific permissions that might exist in the group's or account's customData.

    //process request here
 }
        Parameters:
        httpServletRequest - an javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest instance.
        Returns:
        an ApiAuthenticationResult if the API request was authenticated successfully.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the method argument is null or is not a javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest instance.
        Since:
        1.0.RC4.6
        See Also:
        ServletOAuthRequestAuthenticator.authenticate(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest)
